string.value:
Welcome to the MAKING HISTORY tutorial!
This six part tutorial is designed to quickly introduce you to key elements of the game. You will explore the game interface, learn to command military units, forge alliances and trades, invest in research, and manage economic production.
The tutorial's six sections are: 1. Game Interface and Events 2. Military 3. Diplomacy 4. Production 5. Research 6. Resources
This tutorial will take approximately 30 minutes. To quit at any time, click on the home button at the bottom left of the tutorial panel.
Click on Next to begin.
The Operational map occupies two-thirds of your screen. From this map you can view and manage military forces, cities, regions, and resources.
To the left of this text is the Mini Map. Clicking anywhere in the Mini Map will instantly move you to that location on the world map.
In the Mini Map, click on the USA.
To travel on the Operational map, you can use your keyboard arrows or mouse to move in any direction.
Use the keyboard's up arrow to move north into Canada.
When using the mouse, you can drag the map to change your view.
Pan west by clicking anywhere on the map and dragging right.
With the keyboard's number pad you can tilt (8 and 2) and zoom (+ and -) your map view.
Tilt your view and zoom in and out.
On the World Map, your default view is of the country you're playing. To return to this view, click on the Czechoslovakian flag.

The info bar lives at the top of the world map. Here you can check the date, turn number, and turn length.
There's also data on resource supplies and stockpiles, which you'll learn more about later.

To win in MAKING HISTORY, you gather Power Points.
Scores for all playable countries are included, even when they're played by the computer. In this tutorial, it's just little Czechoslovakia against Germany...

Next, let's explore the right hand panels. Here you'll learn about and manage the game world.
The right hand panel can be broken into three sections: top, middle, and bottom.

These icons take you to the five main areas of MAKING HISTORY: Turn Summary, Military, Diplomacy, Domestic, and Economy.
If you don't see the Turn Summary panel:

When you click on a policy icon, a policy panel will appear. Here you'll find information and actions for that policy area.
When you click on map objects, their information also appears in this panel.
In these policy panels, you will determine your nation's future.

From the System bar you can end turns, save or quit games, and access additional game data.
Ending a turn moves the game ahead one week. In that time, military orders are processed, finances calculated, materials produced, and scores updated.
Map objects are icons on the Operational map. They include cities, military units, battles, and resource producers (oil wells, coal mines, and metals foundries).

The first object you'll explore is your capital, Prague.
How can you find it? Well, all map objects (cities, units, resource producers) have tooltips and all capital cities have flags.
To view a tooltip, move your mouse cursor over an object. You can learn the strength of a military unit, the production capacity of an oil well, or, in this case, the name of a city.

A green circle will appear to show your capital has been selected.
Look to the right. Note that clicking on Prague has brought up its city panel. In Lesson 4: Production, you'll learn about this panel.
Now try clicking on other objects. Click on a foreign city, a military unit, or a resource producer. The ESC button on your keyboard deselects objects from the map.
Press ESC to clear the right hand panel.
You've now seen all basic elements of the MAKING HISTORY interface. The next screens of this lesson will introduce you to notifications and turn summaries.

Germany has declared war against Czechoslovakia!
All major global events appear in 'pop up' notifications like this. These include important alliances and declarations of war.
To continue playing, you must read your notification and click OK.

Major and minor events appear in the Turn Summary panel.
When you end a turn, the next turn opens with this panel.
You can always click on the Globe icon to access the Turn Summary.

Congratulations, you've completed your first lesson!
In Lesson 1: Game Interface, you learned: - basic elements of the game interface - how to navigate the world map - how to select objects on the map - how to review world events
In the next lesson, you'll learn about managing your military. Since Germany has declared war on you, the sooner you can rally your forces, the better!
To continue to Lesson 2: Military, click on the End Turn button.
In this lesson, you'll learn the basics of military defense. The focus will be on land units--your army. You'll learn about attacks, review military units, and move ground units.

First, let's review the Turn Summary. Uh oh, Germany has seized the Sudetenland!
Look at Czechoslovakia on the Operational map--there's a Nazi unit in the Sudetenland and the region is now Germany's color!

All military movements occur in end turn processing. Germany planned its attack in turn one and the German unit moved during turn processing.
You can see military units surrounding your nation, but you only learn about an attack when it happens--when it appears on the map and in the Turn Summary.

Germany's attack was so strong that you lost the Sudetenland region.
To survive in MAKING HISTORY, you need regions. Specifically, you need the population, factories, and resources that are in regions.
If you lose all your land, you will be forced to surrender--Game Over.

You'll defend Czechoslovakia with your primary units (land forces) and support units (sea and air forces).
Primary units belong to your army and are the only units that can control land regions. You need your army to defend and conquer regions.

Support units (air and sea) can damage enemy units and possessions, but cannot control land regions.
Air units can perform reconnaissance and bomb objects on the Operational map.
With sea units you can patrol, battle enemy forces, blockade ports, and escort troop transports.
Now that you've learned a little about your military, it's time to learn how to fight. Use tooltips to locate the Czechoslovak region of Bohemia.
Click on the 3rd Army group in Bohemia.
A green circle will show that the 3rd Army group has been selected. You will now order the 3rd Army to move to the Sudetenland.
Right click anywhere in the Sudetenland.
A green arrow has appeared, tracing the 3rd Army's path. When you click End Turn, the 3rd Army will move into the Sudetenland, and attack the German division in the region.
In the Sudetenland, you'll see a new icon--an explosion! This represents a military engagement. The winner of this battle gains control of the region.

In this report, you can compare your power to Germany's. Also, you can see how many divisions are in battle and how many have been destroyed.
There are only two sides in any engagement, but multiple countries can join the fight--if Czechoslovakia had any allies, they could assist you in this battle.
The combat report is dispiriting. Germany's forces are far more powerful than Czechoslovakia's. You will surely lose this engagement.

You have completed Lesson 2: Military. In this lesson, you learned: - how to track military attacks - the importance of controlling regions - the differences between primary and support units - how to move an army division and attack - how to review combat
In the next lesson, you'll learn about Diplomacy--and just in time. The Czechoslovakian military is no match for the German army. You need international support to survive.
To continue to Lesson 3: Diplomacy, click on the End Turn button.

In this lesson, you'll learn how to propose treaties and request alliances.
Diplomatic help will be crucial, as Czechoslovakia is in a dire state. Germany controls the Sudetenland, and the German forces are far more powerful than Czechoslovakia's.
Germany has allied with Italy! Czechoslovakia definitely needs its own allies.
Click OK to close the box.
After reviewing your Turn Summary, you'll want to check out your Diplomatic policies, found in the Diplomacy panel.

Near the top of the Diplomacy panel is a list of your alliances. You have none.
Below this is a list of your enemies. Unfortunately, that list is not blank.

Clicking on the Alliances and Wars button displays every nation's friends and enemies.
Under Negotiations, you can propose treaties to a nation or an alliance. Under Ratified Agreements, you can see what treaties you currently have.
Is Germany at war with any other countries? Perhaps the enemy of your enemy can become your friend.
In this panel, you can see all global conflicts and alliances.
Czechoslovakia's situation looks bad. If you sacrifice the Sudetenland, will Germany leave you alone? From the Negotiations section, let's propose a treaty to Germany.
You're now looking at the nation panel for Germany. You can see its population, production, and power. Also, from here you can propose peace.
The two tabs allow you to make demands of and offer concessions to your enemies. You're not in a position to be making any demands.
You can offer one to four concessions. When you click on them, the checkmark shows they have been selected.
Rejected! It appears the Nazis want all Czechoslovakia. Who will come to your aid?

The United Kingdom is the world's most powerful empire. Let's ask for an alliance--the worst the UK can do is say no.
You'll want to go to the United Kingdom nation panel, but instead of getting there through the Diplomacy panel, this time you'll use the Operational map. On the map, you'll reach the UK by using the arrow keys or your mouse.
You are now looking at the United Kingdom's nation panel. From here you can propose an alliance.
The UK has agreed to ally with you!

The power of the British Empire now backs Czechoslovakia!
You are united with the UK and with its allies. All those nations have joined your war against Germany and Italy.

Congratulations! You've finished Lesson 3: Diplomacy. In this lesson you learned: - how to review alliances and wars - how to propose peace - how to request an alliance
German troops are still in your land, but with your new allies, Czechoslovakia's chances of survival have increased.
To continue to Lesson 4: Production, click Next.

In this lesson, you'll learn how to build weaponry, which will help your military and your economy.
Czechoslovakia needs the economic boost; you've allied with the UK, but still must hold off Germany until British forces arrive.
All production takes place in cities, so let's start this lesson by returning to your capital city.

In the city panel, you'll see numbers with IPUs and MPUs. What are these labels?
IPUs Your cities need Industrial Production Units to build. A weapon, arms, or good's IPU requirement depends on its size and complexity. A city's IPU number represents its per turn production capacity (i.e. how much the city can produce).
MPUs To produce goods, you also need workers. A city's MPU number represents how many workers live there.
Now let's take a look what Prague is producing. In the city panel:

In the Production Orders box, each tabbed section lists different production options. These lists are the same for your cities with the same technology level. Also, port cities can build naval forces.

Prague's current order--goods--is highlighted in green. Workers need goods to produce at full capacity and surplus goods can generate income on the World Market. But, in wartime, priorities change; you want to build weaponry, increase production, upgrade industry, and invest in research.
From the Land Forces section, you can start building land units.
Click on the Land Forces tab.
Basic Infantry has turned green, to show it's been selected. Basic Infantry requires 100 IPUs, and Prague's production capacity is 20 IPUs per turn, so it will take five turns to build the unit.
Production will start when you end the turn, but before you do that, let's explore another aspect of city production.
Click on the gold bars icon.

You can oversee all financial activities in the Economy panel.
Take a look at National Income and National Spending. Is your Treasury in the red or the black?
From the Czechoslovakian Industry button, you can review production for all cities.
In the Production Centers box you can review and change city production orders.
You've switched production in Brno from Goods to Basic Infantry. Again, this new production order will start when you end the turn.

Congratulations! You've finished Lesson 4: Production. In this lesson you learned: - how to review production - how to issue new build orders from a city panel - how to issue new build orders from the production panel.
To continue to Lesson 5: Research, click on End Turn.

In the last lesson, you began expanding your military by building Basic Infantry units. What about more advanced weaponry?
To build bomber planes and advanced armored forces, you first must develop them. In this short lesson you'll learn how to invest in research.
Research projects can be found in MAKING HISTORY's Domestic policy panel.
In this panel you can see population and workforce data, liberate occupied regions, and see your investment in research. (You invest by choosing research in city production orders.)
The first thing you'll see is a Research Report. This lists all projects you have in progress, how many city IPUs you've dedicated to research, and how much you're spending per turn on research.
MAKING HISTORY's 70+ research projects are divided into five research areas. Let's explore.
In this panel, note that completed projects are blue, projects in progress are green, available projects are tan, and projects beyond your research abilities are gray.
Each research project is described, with its effects, financial costs, and research point costs.
You've selected your first research project.
To support your project, you will also need to assign IPUs to research under City Production.

You've finished the research section of this tutorial. In this lesson, you: - reviewed the domestic panel - reviewed research projects - started a new research project.
This lesson was short, but important. For most nations, research projects are crucial to long-term success; you want to be as advanced or more advanced than your enemies.
To continue to the tutorial's last section, Lesson 6: Resources, click on End Turn.
In this final lesson, you'll learn about resources (coal, metals, and oil). The tutorial will show you how to acquire resources through trade and infrastructure investments.

Look at the Turn Summary. You have an oil shortage!
Without resources, cities can't complete production orders. You can see resource levels in the Info bar.
To see resource details, let's return to Czechoslovakian Industry, in the Economy panel.
Click on the gold bars icon.
From the Industrial Production box, you'll want to go to the Supplies section.
You can gain resources by upgrading regional resource producers, conquering resource-rich regions, buying from the World Market, or requesting international aid.
To gain resources, you'll want to leave the Industrial Production box.
Asking for aid might be your best bet, so let's explore that option.
In the Trade Negotiations panel you can offer and request aid, and buy and sell on the World Market.

Who might give you aid?
You're not allied with the French, but they might support you economically.
The steps to request aid are the same as the steps to buy and sell supplies.
Click on the Oil icon tab.
You can now select a nation and make your request.
France has agreed to send aid! You'll receive oil every turn, unless you or France cancel the deal.
Now that you've successfully set up an aid treaty, you can leave the World Market.

You can also increase resources by maximizing resource production.
From the Operational map you can maximize by clicking on resource icons (oil wells, coal mines, or metal foundries).
Or, from the Infrastructure panel, you can make changes across all regions.

In the Regions panel of Infrastructure, you can upgrade food production, transportation, or defenses for all territories you control. You can also make these upgrades by clicking on a region from the Operational map.
To expand production, you'll want to view the Resource Producers panel.
You don't produce oil, but you can maximize coal production.

The button will turn green, to show that upgrades are in process. While maximized, the Moravian mine's production will expand slowly until it is double the normal rate, but at increased manpower and money costs.

You have finished Lesson 6: Resources. In this lesson, you learned how to: - monitor resource and supply levels - request international aid - maximize resource production.
Resource management and growth are crucial to surviving and succeeding in MAKING HISTORY. Without these supplies, your factories cannot build and your armies cannot fight.

Congratulations! You've finished the MAKING HISTORY tutorial. You now have the basic skills and knowledge needed to play the game.
To learn more about MAKING HISTORY, we recommend you review the Game Manual or the in-game Encyclopedia.
You can also visit the MAKING HISTORY forum, where MAKING HISTORY players and designers discuss game strategies.
Good luck and game on!
To exit the tutorial, click on Next or the home icon.
